metadata.title: Plants: Structure and Function
metadata.subject: Science
metadata.description: This chapter details the primary parts of a plant—root, stem, and leaf—and explores their specific structures and vital functions, which work together to help the plant survive and grow.

concepts.title: The Root
concepts.content: The root is the part of the plant that typically grows underground. Its main functions are to anchor the plant in the soil, absorb water and essential mineral nutrients, and in some cases, store food.

examples.text: Taproots, like in a carrot or radish, have one main thick root with smaller branches and are excellent for food storage.
Fibrous roots, found in grass and onion, are a dense network of thin roots that are great for preventing soil erosion.
Prop roots of a Banyan tree grow down from branches to provide extra support.

keyPoints.text: The root cap protects the growing tip of the root.
Root hairs vastly increase the surface area for water absorption.
There are two main types: Taproot system and Fibrous root system.

concepts.funFact: Some orchids have aerial roots that never touch the soil and absorb moisture directly from the air!

concepts.title: The Stem
concepts.content: The stem is the main axis of the plant that grows above the ground. It supports the leaves, flowers, and fruits, positioning them to get sunlight. It also functions as a transport system, carrying water and nutrients from the roots to the leaves, and food from the leaves to other parts.

examples.text: Nodes are the points on the stem where leaves arise.
The potato is a modified underground stem (tuber) that stores starch.
The stem of a watermelon plant is a creeper that runs along the ground.

keyPoints.text: The stem consists of nodes and internodes.
It contains xylem and phloem tissues for transport.
Stems can be modified for food storage, support (tendrils), or protection (thorns).

concepts.funFact: The trunk of a giant sequoia tree is a massive stem that can be over 30 feet in diameter!

concepts.title: The Leaf
concepts.content: The leaf is a flattened, green part of the plant that is attached to the stem. It is the primary site of photosynthesis, the process by which plants use sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide to create their own food (glucose).

examples.text: A simple leaf has a single, undivided leaf blade (e.g., mango leaf).
A compound leaf has a blade divided into multiple leaflets (e.g., neem leaf).
The arrangement of veins on a leaf is called venation (reticulate or parallel).

keyPoints.text: The green color comes from a pigment called chlorophyll.
Stomata are tiny pores, usually on the underside of leaves, for gas exchange (CO2 in, O2 out).
Transpiration, the loss of water vapor, also occurs through stomata.

concepts.funFact: The Venus flytrap has modified leaves that snap shut to catch and digest insects, providing it with extra nutrients!

test.question: What is the name for the arrangement of veins in a leaf?
test.explanation: Venation refers to the pattern of veins in the blade of a leaf.

test.question: A potato is an example of a modified:
test.explanation: A potato is a tuber, which is a swollen underground stem modified for storing starch.

test.question: Which type of root system is best at preventing soil erosion?
test.explanation: The dense, web-like structure of fibrous roots holds soil particles together effectively, preventing erosion.

test.question: What is the function of the root cap?
options: To protect the growing root tip
test.explanation: The root cap is a tough layer of cells that protects the delicate meristematic tissue as the root pushes through the soil.

test.question: The process of losing water vapor through the stomata of leaves is called:
test.explanation: Transpiration is the evaporation of water from the plant's surfaces, primarily the leaves.

test.question: Which tissues in the stem are responsible for transporting water and food?
test.explanation: Xylem transports water and minerals up from the roots, while phloem transports sugars (food) from the leaves to other parts of the plant.

test.question: Onions and grass have which type of root system?
test.explanation: Both onions and grasses have a fibrous root system, characterized by a mass of similarly sized roots.

test.question: The 'kitchen' of the plant, where food is made, is the:
test.explanation: Leaves are where photosynthesis happens, which is the process of making food for the plant.

commonMisconceptions: Plants breathe in the same way animals do.

longAnswers.question: Describe the structure of a typical flower in your own words.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: A typical flower consists of four main parts: Calyx, Corolla, Androecium, and Gynoecium. The Calyx is the outermost green part (sepals) that protects the flower in the bud stage. The Corolla is the colorful part made of petals that attracts insects. The Androecium is the male reproductive part consisting of stamens (anther and filament). The Gynoecium is the female reproductive part consisting of carpels (stigma, style, and ovary). These parts are arranged on the thalamus, which is the expanded end of the flower stalk or pedicel.
keyPoints: Corolla: Colorful petals to attract pollinators.
Gynoecium: Female part with carpels (stigma, style, ovary).

longAnswers.question: What is the difference between Tap Roots and Fibrous Roots?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Dicotyledonous plants usually have a tap root system, which consists of a primary root that grows deep into the soil and produces secondary roots. In contrast, monocotyledonous plants have a fibrous root system, where a cluster of thin, thread-like roots grows from the base of the stem. Tap roots provide stronger anchorage and go deeper, while fibrous roots are more spread out near the surface.
keyPoints: Tap roots: One main primary root with branches (Dicot plants).
Fibrous roots: Cluster of thin roots from the stem base (Monocot plants).
Tap roots provide better deep anchorage; fibrous roots spread wide.

longAnswers.question: Explain the process of germination of a seed.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Germination is the process by which a seed develops into a new plant. When a seed receives proper water, air, and warmth, the embryo inside begins to grow. The part that grows towards the soil is called the radicle (which becomes the root), and the part that grows upwards out of the soil is called the plumule (which becomes the shoot). As the plant grows, it uses the food stored in the seed until it can perform photosynthesis.
keyPoints: Radicle grows downwards into the soil (becomes root).
Plumule grows upwards out of the soil (becomes shoot).
